places.name: Northumberland
places.description: County in the North East of England. It borders Scotland to the north and the county of Cumbria to the west.

places.name: Ganges
places.description: The Ganges is a river in Asia running through India and Bangladesh. It is part of the third largest river on earth.

persons.name: William ThomasBrande
persons.description: Originally trained as an apothecary, Brande became a chemist. With Davy and others founded the Animal Chemistry Club. Lectured on chemistry in various London institutions and, following Davy's retirement succeeded him in his positions at the Royal Institution where he founded The Quarterly Journal of Science. A Secretary of the Royal Society of London, 1816-1826; later fell out with Davy. FRSL.

places.name: La Grave
places.description: a commune in the Hautes-Alpes department in southeastern France.

places.name: River Thames
places.description: The River Thames, known alternatively in parts as the River Isis, is a river that flows through southern England including London.

places.name: Edinburgh
places.description: The capital city of Scotland.

places.name: Greenwich
places.description: In south-east london, on the banks of the River Thames, it is a famous maritime site.

places.name: Pacific Ocean
places.description: The largest and deepest of Earth's five oceans.

persons.name: John FredericDaniell
persons.description: First Professor of Chemistry at King's College London. Developed the first battery that produced a constant flow of electricity.

persons.name: William ThomasBrande
persons.description: Originally trained as an apothecary, Brande became a chemist. With Davy and others founded the Animal Chemistry Club. Lectured on chemistry in various London institutions and, following Davy's retirement succeeded him in his positions at the Royal Institution where he founded The Quarterly Journal of Science. A Secretary of the Royal Society of London, 1816-1826; later fell out with Davy. FRSL.

persons.name: CharlesHatchett
persons.description: He made his money from coach building which he used to pursue his interests in chemistry and mineralogy in the course of which he isolated the chemical element now called niobium. He was a Manager of the Royal Institution, playing a key role especially in running its lecture programme during the 1800s. FRSL.

persons.name: JÃ¶ns JacobBerzelius
persons.description: Swedish chemist. He discovered the chemical elements cerium and selenium, and was the first to isolate silicon, thorium, titanium, and zirconium. A rival of Davy's whom he met a few times.

persons.name: BertrandPelletier
persons.description: French pharmacist and chemist who conducted researches on chlorine and phosphorus.

places.name: Bristol
places.description: A city in south-western England.

places.name: London
places.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

persons.name: ThomasHarrison
persons.description: Lawyer and Secretary of the Royal Institution, 1813-1824. FRSL.

places.name: Yorkshire
places.description: Yorkshire is a historic county in northern England and the largest by area size in the United Kingdom.

places.name: Elsecar
places.description: Elsecar is a mining village near Barnsley.

places.name: Cumberland
places.description: Cumberland is a historic county in the far north-west of England.

persons.name: LuigiGalvani
persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

places.name: Elsecar
places.description: Elsecar is a mining village near Barnsley.

persons.name: William ThomasBrande
persons.description: Originally trained as an apothecary, Brande became a chemist. With Davy and others founded the Animal Chemistry Club. Lectured on chemistry in various London institutions and, following Davy's retirement succeeded him in his positions at the Royal Institution where he founded The Quarterly Journal of Science. A Secretary of the Royal Society of London, 1816-1826; later fell out with Davy. FRSL.

places.name: Greenland
places.description: Greenland lies between the Arctic and Atlantic oceans, east of the Canadian Arctic Archipelago. It is the world's largest island, and is the location of the northernmost area of the world.

persons.name: Daniel GabrielFahrenheit
persons.description: German physicist, inventor, and scientific instrument maker, who invented the mercury-in-glass thermometer. The temperature scale he proposed is named after him. ForMemRSL.

places.name: Windsor
places.description: Windsor is a historic market town in the Royal Borough of Windsor and Maidenhead in Berkshire.

places.name: Windsor
places.description: Windsor is a historic market town in the Royal Borough of Windsor and Maidenhead in Berkshire.

places.name: Catherineberg
places.description: Siberia, probably modern Yekaterinburg.

places.name: Siberia
places.description: a vast Russian province encompassing most of Northern Asia, with terrain spanning tundra, coniferous forest and mountain ranges

persons.name: John HenryVivian
persons.description: He owned copper mining, copper smelting and trading businesses in Swansea (Vivian & Sons), Liverpool, Birmingham and London. From 1806, manager of the copper works at Penclawdd. FRS.

persons.name: William ThomasBrande
persons.description: Originally trained as an apothecary, Brande became a chemist. With Davy and others founded the Animal Chemistry Club. Lectured on chemistry in various London institutions and, following Davy's retirement succeeded him in his positions at the Royal Institution where he founded The Quarterly Journal of Science. A Secretary of the Royal Society of London, 1816-1826; later fell out with Davy. FRSL.

persons.name: Charles JosephHullmandel
persons.description: London lithographer, tutored by Faraday in chemistry to improve lithographic processes.

persons.name: JosephBramah
persons.description: English inventor and locksmith.

persons.name: DavidGordon
persons.description: Inventor and patentee of a system of compressing portable gas, discussed by Brande.

persons.name: John GeorgeChildren
persons.description: English chemist, mineralogist, and zoologist, and a friend of Davy's. Children invented a method to extract silver from ore without the need for mercury. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamGilbert
persons.description: English physician, man of science, and author of the influential treatise De Magnete (1600).

persons.name: John AyrtonParis
persons.description: Physician, chemist and author and member of the Royal Institution. In 1831 published a biography of Davy that John Davy criticised severely in his 1836 biography of his brother. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamBuckland
persons.description: Anglican priest who was later Dean of Westminster. Perhaps the last serious geologist to attempt the reconciliation of the findings of contemporary geology with the Biblical accounts. FRSL.

places.name: Florence
places.description: The capital city of the Italian region of Tuscany.

places.name: Florence
places.description: The capital city of the Italian region of Tuscany.

persons.name: Rene-AntoineRÃ©aumur
persons.description: French entomologist who developed a widely used temperature scale. ForMemRSL.

places.name: Florence
places.description: The capital city of the Italian region of Tuscany.

persons.name: JosephBramah
persons.description: English inventor and locksmith.

persons.name: AndrÃ©-MarieAmpÃ¨re
persons.description: French physicist and mathematician and one of the key figure in the early study of electro-magnetism. Davy met him in Paris in 1813 and they developed a scientific rivalry. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Moses
persons.description: According to the Old Testament Hebrew prophet who is considered the most important prophet in Judaism and one of the most important prophets in Christianity and other religions.

places.name: Guernsey
places.description: One of the Channel Islands in the English Channel near the French coast.

persons.name: AndrewDrummond
persons.description: Scottish founder of Drummond's Bank, Charing Cross, in 1717. Davy banked there and with its successor, Drummond and Morland and Company.

places.name: Windsor
places.description: Windsor is a historic market town in the Royal Borough of Windsor and Maidenhead in Berkshire.

persons.name: JohnJonston
persons.description: Polish scholar, physician and naturalist descended from Scottish nobility. Closely associated with the Polish magnate LeszczyÅski family.

persons.name: GeorgeSpencer
persons.description: From 1758, 4th Duke of Marlborough. British courtier, nobleman and politician. FRSL.

persons.name: Jeremias BenjaminRichter
persons.description: German chemist who worked on the idea of definite proportions.

persons.name: MatthewBaillie
persons.description: Physician and brother of Joanna Baillie. One of the doctors who saw Davy during his serious illness from late 1807 to early 1808. FRSL.

persons.name: Jeremias BenjaminRichter
persons.description: German chemist who worked on the idea of definite proportions.

persons.name: EverardHome
persons.description: Prominent London surgeon. FRSL.

places.name: Malvern, Worcestershire
places.description: Malvern is a spa town and civil parish in Worcestershire. It lies at the foot of the Malvern Hills.

persons.name: Henry ThomasColebrooke
persons.description: English orientalist and mathematician. He has been described as 'the first great Sanskrit scholar in Europe'. FRSL.

persons.name: Jean-BaptisteDumas
persons.description: French chemist, best known for his works on organic analysis and synthesis, as well as the determination of atomic and molecular weights by measuring vapour densities. ForMemRSL.

places.name: Newcastle upon Tyne
places.description: Newcastle upon Tyne is a city in the north-east of England. It is located on the River Tyne's northern bank.

persons.name: William HaseldinePepys
persons.description: Pepys was a surgical and scientific instrument maker and chemist. Constructed large batteries used by Davy (amongst others). FRSL.

places.name: Andes
places.description: Mountain range in western South America.

persons.name: JamesBlundell
persons.description: English obstetrician, who performed the first successful transfusion of human blood to a patient for treatment of a haemorrhage.

persons.name: Daniel GabrielFahrenheit
persons.description: German physicist, inventor, and scientific instrument maker, who invented the mercury-in-glass thermometer. The temperature scale he proposed is named after him. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: WilliamBuckland
persons.description: Anglican priest who was later Dean of Westminster. Perhaps the last serious geologist to attempt the reconciliation of the findings of contemporary geology with the Biblical accounts. FRSL.

persons.name: Samuel LathamMitchill
persons.description: American chemist, botanist, natural historian and botanist, who studied medicine at the University of Edinburgh. He claimed nitrous oxide was poisonous (which Davy proved was wrong).

places.name: Wales
places.description: Wales is a country in southwest Great Britain known for its rugged coastline, mountainous national parks, distinctive Welsh language and Celtic culture.

places.name: Merthyr Tydfil
places.description: Merthyr Tydfil is the main town in Merthyr Tydfil County Borough, Wales.

persons.name: Roderick ImpeyMurchison
persons.description: Davy turned Murchison's interests from fox hunting to geology. Developed the Silurian system and served as Director General of the British Geological Survey from 1855 until death. FRSL.

places.name: Sabina
places.description: Also called the Sabine Hills, a region in central Italy.

places.name: Tyrol
places.description: Tyrol is a historical region in the Alps located in northern Italy and western Austria.

places.name: Greenwich
places.description: In south-east london, on the banks of the River Thames, it is a famous maritime site.

places.name: Sabina
places.description: Also called the Sabine Hills, a region in central Italy.

persons.name: William VarloHellyer
persons.description: Lawyer and later a Manager of the Royal Institution.

places.name: Regent's Park
places.description: A park in north-west inner London.

persons.name: GeorgeSpencer
persons.description: From 1758, 4th Duke of Marlborough. British courtier, nobleman and politician. FRSL.

places.name: Palmyra
places.description: Palmyra is an ancient city in the eastern part of the Levant, now in the centre of modern Syria.

persons.name: T.Griffiths
persons.description: Dates untraced; an article in Transactions of the Society, Instituted at London, for the Encouragement of Arts, Manufactures, and Commerce gives a decription of his improved version of the stop-cock for chemical purposes, for which he was awarded the Silver Vulcan medal.

persons.name: Johann RudolfGlauber
persons.description: German-Dutch alchemist and chemist. He discovered sodium sulphate in 1625 which was named 'Glauber's salt'.

persons.name: JohnNewman
persons.description: Scientific instrument maker of Lisle Street, and afterwards of Regent-street. Instrument maker to the Royal Institution who made the earliest Davy safety lamps.

persons.name: Charles A.Clarke
persons.description: Landscape painter who exhibited a few times at the Royal Academy.

places.name: Cavendish Street
places.description: New Cavendish Street is a street in the City of Westminster, London, that runs from Marylebone High Street in the west to Cleveland Street in the east. The street was built in 1775 and named after the Cavendish family, who were related to the ground landlords, the Dukes of Portland.

places.name: Park Street, Hertfordshire
places.description: Davy's home from 1825.
